Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing Arctic Ice Sheet Sensitivity to Abrupt Climate Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
A team of investigators proposes to investigate the response of the Laurentide and Greenland Ice Sheets to two short term cooling events (several decades to a few centuries in duration) that occurred 9.3 and 8.2 thousand years ago. Assessing the sensitivity of ice sheets to short term climate variability is at the forefront of the scientific community's and the public's interest because short term ice sheet change will drive 21st century sea level rise. Thus a central question of the proposed work is whether ice sheets react abruptly to climate forcings, or are multi-millennial-scale trends in climate required to elicit a large-scale ice sheet response?

The investigators propose an intensive field-based research program capitalizing on their newly published work reconstructing ice sheet change using high-precision beryllium-10 dating to test the hypothesis that prominent moraine systems marking former ice extents in West Greenland and Baffin Island record the synchronous advance of the Greenland and Laurentide ice sheets driven by the abrupt cooling events 9.3 and 8.2 thousand years ago. Pilot data reveal that portions of the ice sheet margin that are in contact with the surrounding ocean are able to respond rapidly to a short-lived climate perturbation. To test whether these documented changes were restricted to solely the most sensitive marine-terminating ice sheet sectors, or whether ice sheets are capable of a larger scale response to centennial-scale climate change, well-constrained chronologies of ice sheet change are needed from other regions. The investigators' research objectives are to 1) establish how land-terminating regions of ice sheets, which are more representative of broader ice sheet margins, respond to abrupt climate change, 2) further evaluate the role that oceanic forcing plays in modulating ice sheet response to short-lived climate perturbations, and 3) reconstruct the early Holocene behavior of mountain glacier systems (a proxy for summertime temperature) to evaluate what climatic conditions influenced the ice sheets. The investigators will work to make results easily accessible to the public. The work is led by an early career investigator and will support two graduate and several undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Between approximately 12,000 and 7,000 years ago, the Greenland Ice Sheet and, what was then the Laurentide Ice Sheet, experienced significant recession. This large-scale ice-sheet recession occurred under the backdrop of temperatures in the Arctic that were as warm or slightly warmer than today. During overall ice sheet recession, the margins of both the Greenland and Laurentide ice sheets paused and/or readvanced and deposited moraines, which are large piles of glacial debris that mark former glacier dimensions. The existence of these moraines has long been recognized, but the exact timing of when these moraines were deposited is largely unknown. Determining when the Greenland and Laurentide ice sheets interrupted their overall retreat between approximately 12,000 and 7,000 years ago provides key insights into the mechanisms driving ice-sheet change.

Here, we found that pauses or readvances of the Greenland and Laurentide ice sheet margins occurred in unison around 11,800-11,600, 10,400, 9,300, and 8,200 years ago. Each of these episodes of moraine deposition occurred in concert with a series of known abrupt cold reversals that were superimposed on Arctic warming at this time. It is likely that these abrupt cold reversals repeatedly halted glacier and ice sheet recession. Results also revealed that independent alpine glaciers not connected to the Greenland or Laurentide ice sheets readvanced at the same time. Because the timing of glacier change during these events in the same, from small glaciers to ice sheets, it indicates that large ice sheets can respond to short-lived climate perturbations on timescales that are comparable to the response times of climate sensitive alpine glaciers. Our findings indicate that ice sheets do not have long response times and like their smaller alpine counterparts, are able to equilibrate to climate relatively quickly. Today's ice sheet changes include both responses to climate but also to a variety of complicated ice dynamics processes. When one looks beyond the year to decade scale, rather multiple decades up to a century, climate dominates and large ice sheets are very sensitive to climate change.

Results from this project have implications regarding what caused abrupt cooling between ~12,000 and 7,000 years ago and how do ice sheets respond and/or drive this cooling. A likely scenario is that meltwater from ice sheets gets pumped into the Labrador Sea region, cooling regional climate by disrupting ocean circulation, which in turn causes ice sheets to pause and/or readvance during overall ice-margin retreat. This general framework may have implications for the current demise of the Greenland Ice Sheet as recent observations suggest that regional ocean circulation is beginning to be disrupted in fashion similar to the changes in ocean circulation that occurred approximately 12,000 to 7,000 years ago. These results point to a feedback mechanism inherent to melting ice sheets in the Baffin Bay region: increased meltwater from ice sheets results in brief episodes of regional cooling, which briefly allows the ice sheet margins to pause overall ice-margin recession.

This award supported a new early-career researcher, fostered new collaborations between researchers at different academic institutions, and results have been presented at a number of professional conferences. Results have been distributed to the public through participation in the annual Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory Open House, which typically receives ~3,000 visitors.
